awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Quadrupole/Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer with Ion Mobility Separations for Faculty and Student Research in the Susquehanna Valley
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Bucknell University is acquiring a high-pressure liquid-chromatograph ion mobility, quadrupole mass spectrometer (HPLC-IM-Q-TOF) to support Professor Douglas Collins and colleagues Moria Chambers and Lou Tom from Susquehanna University. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex samples. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are made into ions and the ions' masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows the structure of molecules in complex mixtures to be studied. An instrument with a liquid chromatograph can separate mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer's analyzer. The ion mobility (IM) component provides a method that separates gas phase ions based on their interactions with a gas depending on their masses. Initially, the ions are quickly separated and then they are introduced into the mass analyzer. This complex instrument is useful to analyze samples from the human body (proteomics and metabolomics). The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the university and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by enabling diverse students to gain familiarity with this modern analytical technique. The HPLC-IM-Q-TOF is also used in outreach activities involving students from Susquehanna University.

The award of the mass spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts exploration of supramolecular host-guest chemistry and mechanistic studies of porous and the formation of crystalline covalent organic frameworks (COF). The instrumentation is used for controlling peptide secondary structure through metal interactions. In addition, it provides information to understand multiphase chemistry of complex organic films. The mass spectrometer is used to explore the effect of third hand smoke on indoor surfaces and for the study of photodegradation of pharmaceuticals. This instrument is also used in the identification of antimicrobials in fireflies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In 2020, Bucknell University was awarded $391,544 through a Track 1 Major Research Instrumentation grant for the acquisition of a major piece of chemical analysis equipment called a quadrupole/time-of-flight mass spectrometer. With this equipment, faculty and students at Bucknell University and Susquehanna University have been able to chemically characterize a wide variety of materials to enable new and leading-edge research. The instrument was made available, and remains so, for no-cost access to researchers from any primarily undergradute institution in the region. This access model aligns with the smaller research budgets often maintained at smaller institutions of higher education, particularly those who primarily serve undergraduate students, and the instrument has catalyzed progress on a variety of research themes.

Enabling New Research Across Science and Engineering. This award has enabled research at Bucknell University and Susquehanna University that cuts across chemistry, materials science, biochemistry, air quality, environmental remediation, immunology, physiology, and climate science. New research on tobacco smoke residue sheds light on the way that we understand the toxicological impact of cigarette smoke that has been adhered to indoor surfaces (a key exposure pathway). Studies of antimicrobial chemicals naturally produced by the common eastern firefly are advancing scientific understanding of potential therapeutic agents that could address the emerging antibiotic resistance crisis. The equipment has enabled the characterization of new synthetic chemicals that advance fundamental research on how molecules with unique structural properties can specifically recognize and capture other molecules and/or help grow crystalline solids where traditional methods are too challenging. Nascent projects focused on environmental science questions in areas of critical importance to society. The acquired equipment will be used by one research group to detect chemicals left behind by ancient microbes that can give us information about Earth’s history, and a separate team of engineers will use the equipment to enable their studies to devise a methods for trapping and remove so-called ‘forever chemicals’ from contaminated soils. The mass spectrometer will continue to enable previously intractable research projects for researchers in the Susquehanna Valley of Pennsylvania.

Supporting Faculty/Student Research Teams. The acquired mass spectrometer continues to enable new research trajectories and provide critical support for ongoing scientific and engineering research in the Susquehanna Valley of Pennsylvania. Research teams led by university faculty members and composed mainly of undergraduate students were able to gain access to leading-edge equipment to enable projects that were not previously possible in the region. No-cost access to the mass spectrometer helps to minimize barriers to instrument access and helps to develop projects that are not yet funded and also to support scientific efforts that are primarily educational. Many of the faculty users of the instrument are in the early stages of their independent careers and are utilizing the instrument to develop long-range research trajectories. 

Broadening Participation of Underrepresented Groups in STEM. We have sought to engage students in learning about and using the mass spectrometer across a variety of experience levels. Our goal has been, and continues to be, to use this high-tech equipment to generate excitement and curiosity for students of diverse backgrounds to pursue science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) more deeply. Curricular opportunities have been designed at Bucknell such that every Chemistry and Cell Biology/Biochemistry major will have used the mass spectrometer for a project that requires substantive intellectual engagement with this measurement technique and the data it produces. Therefore, the group of emerging scientists of tomorrow graduating from Bucknell are leaving with experiences that are unique and valuable for their perspectives as they embark on their chosen career paths. The majority of students with academic concentrations in chemistry and cell biology/biochemistry at Bucknell in recent years have been women, who are underrepresented in the broader research communities of these fields.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/07/2024
Modified by: Douglas B Collins
